events.name: EV Battery Supply Chain

events.name: Material Mining
events.wd_description: Material mining involves extracting indispensable materials such as lithium, nickel, cobalt, graphite, and manganese, which are crucial for manufacturing lithium-ion batteries (LBs).

events.name: Lithium Mining
events.wd_description: Lithium is extracted from brine and hard-rock deposits, with major sources in Bolivia, Argentina, Chile, and Australia.

events.name: Nickel Mining
events.wd_description: Nickel is extracted from sulfide and laterite deposits, with significant sources in Russia, Canada, Australia, Indonesia, and the Philippines.

events.name: Cobalt Mining
events.wd_description: Cobalt is primarily mined as a by-product of nickel and copper mining, with major producers including the Democratic Republic of Congo and Switzerland.

events.name: Graphite Mining
events.wd_description: Graphite, used for battery anodes, is primarily mined in China, with additional sources in Tanzania, Mozambique, Canada, and Madagascar.

events.name: Battery Recycling
events.wd_description: Three main methods are used for lithium-ion battery recycling: pyrometallurgical, hydrometallurgical, and bioleaching, with emerging direct recycling methods.
events.description: Three main methods are used for lithium-ion battery recycling: pyrometallurgical, hydrometallurgical, and bioleaching, with emerging direct recycling methods.

events.name: Pyrometallurgical
events.wd_description: This method involves melting the battery in a hot furnace to recover some of the cathode metals, using extreme heat to transform metal oxides into alloys.
events.description: This method involves melting the battery in a hot furnace to recover some of the cathode metals, using extreme heat to transform metal oxides into alloys.

events.name: Hydrometallurgical
events.wd_description: This method involves using aqueous solutions to leach metals out from the cathode substance through specialized solution reagents.
events.description: This method involves using aqueous solutions to leach metals out from the cathode substance through specialized solution reagents.

events.name: Bioleaching
events.wd_description: This method uses bacteria to retrieve precious metals, which is challenging due to the time required for bacterial growth and contamination risks.
events.description: This method uses bacteria to retrieve precious metals, which is challenging due to the time required for bacterial growth and contamination risks.

events.name: Direct Recycling
events.wd_description: Direct recycling involves dismantling anode and cathode components, followed by maintenance, processing, and production for reuse.

events.name: Cobalt Demand Growth
events.wd_description: Cobalt demand reduces during the transition from NMC111 to NMC811, while nickel demand grows progressively.
events.description: Cobalt demand reduces during the transition from NMC111 to NMC811, while nickel demand grows progressively.

events.name: Concentration of Reserves and Production
events.wd_description: Lithium has the highest score for concentration of reserves and production across all chemistries.
events.description: Lithium has the highest score for concentration of reserves and production across all chemistries.

events.name: Lithium Reserves
events.wd_description: Almost half of the global lithium reserves are in Chile, with other reserves in Australia, Argentina, China, and the USA.
events.description: Almost half of the global lithium reserves are in Chile, with other reserves in Australia, Argentina, China, and the USA.

events.name: Lithium Production
events.wd_description: Lithium production is mostly concentrated in Australia, which accounts for nearly 80% of the global production.
events.description: Lithium production is mostly concentrated in Australia, which accounts for nearly 80% of the global production.

events.name: Primary Material Use
events.wd_description: Lithium dominates the primary material use category due to its low recycling potential at the end-of-life.
events.description: Lithium dominates the primary material use category due to its low recycling potential at the end-of-life.

events.name: Lithium Use
events.wd_description: The primary material use of lithium is critical due to its low recycling potential.
events.description: The primary material use of lithium is critical due to its low recycling potential.

events.name: Graphite Use
events.wd_description: Graphite contributes to criticality scores in primary material use due to low recycling potentials.
events.description: Graphite contributes to criticality scores in primary material use due to low recycling potentials.

events.name: Cobalt Use
events.wd_description: Cobalt also contributes to criticality scores in primary material use due to low recycling potentials.
events.description: Cobalt also contributes to criticality scores in primary material use due to low recycling potentials.

events.name: Company Concentration
events.wd_description: Graphite has the highest impact in company concentration, except for NMC-Si and LMO-LTO chemistries.
events.description: Graphite has the highest impact in company concentration, except for NMC-Si and LMO-LTO chemistries.

events.name: Graphite Production Companies
events.wd_description: A major amount of graphite is produced by a small number of companies in India, China, and Brazil.
events.description: A major amount of graphite is produced by a small number of companies in India, China, and Brazil.

events.name: NMC-Si Chemistries
events.wd_description: NMC-Si chemistries are driven by silicon instead of graphite.
events.description: NMC-Si chemistries are driven by silicon instead of graphite.

events.name: LMO-LTO Chemistries
events.wd_description: LMO-LTO chemistries are driven by copper.
events.description: LMO-LTO chemistries are driven by copper.

events.name: Price Volatility
events.wd_description: Nickel dominates the price volatility category, partly influencing the mining capacity category.
events.description: Nickel dominates the price volatility category, partly influencing the mining capacity category.

events.name: Nickel Price Volatility
events.wd_description: Nickel is the only dominating material in the price volatility category.
events.description: Nickel is the only dominating material in the price volatility category.

events.name: Mining Capacity
events.wd_description: Nickel partly influences the mining capacity category due to its criticality.
events.description: Nickel partly influences the mining capacity category due to its criticality.

events.name: Advanced Warehouse Configurations in EV Battery Supply Chain
events.wd_label: Advanced Warehouse Configurations in EV Battery Supply Chain
events.wd_description: Analysis of different configurations for advanced warehouses in EV battery supply chain to minimize costs and risks.
events.description: Analysis of different configurations for advanced warehouses in EV battery supply chain to minimize costs and risks.

events.name: Scenario A
events.wd_description: The Advanced Warehouse is located 20 km away from the plant, leading to the highest unit cost due to dedicated trips and the presence of a small buffer warehouse at the production site.
events.description: The Advanced Warehouse is located 20 km away from the plant, leading to the highest unit cost due to dedicated trips and the presence of a small buffer warehouse at the production site.

events.name: Scenario B
events.wd_description: The Advanced Warehouse is located inside the production site, reducing the distance to 1 km, making it cheaper than Scenario A but with space constraints requiring redesign of the plant layout.
events.description: The Advanced Warehouse is located inside the production site, reducing the distance to 1 km, making it cheaper than Scenario A but with space constraints requiring redesign of the plant layout.

events.name: Scenario C
events.wd_description: Batteries are directly sent to the production line from the Advanced Warehouse located 20 km away, making it more expensive than Scenario B but cheaper than Scenario A without buffer storage.
events.description: Batteries are directly sent to the production line from the Advanced Warehouse located 20 km away, making it more expensive than Scenario B but cheaper than Scenario A without buffer storage.

events.name: Scenario D
events.wd_description: Direct connection between the supplier plant and the production line without an Advanced Warehouse, resulting in the cheapest configuration but highest supply risk due to the 2,000 km distance.
events.description: Direct connection between the supplier plant and the production line without an Advanced Warehouse, resulting in the cheapest configuration but highest supply risk due to the 2,000 km distance.
